Hi Curran et al:
I have a Tochibata tsuba that I bought from a well-known J=
apanese 
dealer. It is not papered, but, he wrote this info on the bill of =

sale: " The old village of Tochihata eventually became Izumo in 
Shimane P=
refecture;  during early Edo, the tsubako of this village 
specialized in m=
aking tsuba with the ji as carved rope, hence the 
name Tochihata for this =
type of tsuba" [mine is a roped mimi].
From this statement from him, I conj=
ecture that a 'roped' mimi tsuba 
called 'Tochibata' does't refer to a mei =
of "Tochibata", but to 
having been made on the island of Tochibata. It is =
possible that 
there are no tsuba with a mei "Tochibata".  I welcome all co=
rrections 
to the above. 

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Curran Camp=
bell 
<neobliviscar@...> wrote:
>
> List,
> 
> I am hoping a lurker out the=
re might be able to
> comment on Tochibata tsuba. I am familiar with them a=
s
> written up on page 58-59 of Harry Watson's Nihonto
> Koza translation o=
f Kodogu Part 1.
> 
> I've seen a limited number of these over the years,
>=
 and they are distinct enough to me that I feel they
> constitute a distinc=
t _if minor_ school.
> 
> Q1:  Has anyone ever seen a tsuba NBTHK / NTHK pa=
pered
> to Tochibata?
> 
> Q2:  Can anyone point me to further writing on t=
his
> school?
> 
> They tend to be strong solid open tsuba that remind of
>=
 Owari, are thick, yet very clean. The last I saw was
> identical to the on=
e on the bottom of NihontoKoza pg.
> 59 and sold as "Owari".  I suspect the=
 papering
> authorities just designate them "Owari", but hope to
> find an =
either one papered Tochibata or hope to find
> another source beyond the Ni=
honto Koza.
> 
> Thanks in advance,
